channel.title: Morning Briefing · Top
channel.description: Daily AU commercial property briefing — assets, funds, deals, development.

item.title: Gateway Capital buys into Sydney’s Eastern Creek as it seeds $800m fund
item.description: While major property players struggle with redemptions, Gateway Capital has seized on an opportunity to acquire a prime $75m Sydney logistics facility.
item.content:encoded: While major property players struggle with redemptions, Gateway Capital has seized on an opportunity to acquire a prime $75m Sydney logistics facility.

item.title: Dexus sells Flinders Gate complex to Asian investor PAG
item.description: The property giant has sold its prime Melbourne office complex near Federation Square for $260m as it moves to trim debt and focus on higher-returning assets.

item.title: Elanor rejects billionaire Lederer’s claims in $276m fund battle

item.title: Meriton’s Harry Triguboff reveals plans for luxury Brisbane waterfront hotel

item.title: ASIC review of stamp duty reporting could spark super fund splurge on property

item.title: Metrics joins Deicorp as $1.8bn Sydney apartment venture takes shape

item.title: Activeport Group Launches Australia’s First Private Cloud Superhighway
item.description:
Activeport Group (ASX: ATV) has unveiled its Private-Cloud Connect platform, a high-speed, fibre-based network designed to give Australian private cloud operators unprecedented flexibility and performance. The launch marks the first dedicated domestic service to offer variable bandwidth for private cloud connectivity, linking branch offices to cloud infrastructure in leading colocation data centres. Three operators — […]

The post Activeport Group Launches Australia’s First Private Cloud Superhighway appeared first on Small Caps.

item.title: US Rally Could Signal Upside for Australian Small Caps if RBA Follows with Rate Cuts
item.description:
Small-cap stocks in the US surged on Wednesday, defying weakness in some of the market’s largest companies, as investors bet the Federal Reserve will continue cutting interest rates in September. Lower borrowing costs are seen as a tailwind for smaller companies that are more leveraged to the economy and reliant on affordable capital to grow. […]

The post US Rally Could Signal Upside for Australian Small Caps if RBA Follows with Rate Cuts appeared first on Small Caps.

item.title: Battery Age Minerals Identifies High-Grade Rubidium from Multi-Element Assays at Falcon Lake
item.description:
Battery Age Minerals (ASX: BM8) has confirmed significant concentrations of rubidium, caesium, gallium and tantalum from multi-element assays at its Falcon Lake lithium project in Ontario, Canada. The assays complement earlier drilling that returned thick zones of high-grade spodumene mineralisation, positioning Falcon Lake as both a premier hard-rock lithium asset and a potential source of […]

item.title: Blue Energy Restarts Sapphire Gas Production as Petroleum Lease Discussions Continue
item.description:
Blue Energy (ASX: BLU) has successfully reinstated production at its Sapphire coal seam gas (CSG) pilot program in Queensland’s Bowen Basin. The Sapphire 6V well was offline during the June quarter after experiencing mechanical issues, including a down-hole pump blockage and a surface pump unit oil cooling fan failure, causing a halt in gas production. […]

item.title: Reports Trump Will Exempt Gold from Tariffs Boost Market Confidence
item.description:
The global gold market has welcomed reports that US president Donald Trump will exempt the precious metal from his latest round of tariffs, although investors are still awaiting clarification on how the government plans to implement this. Gold rose to US$3,358.70 per ounce overnight on the back of the news, along with growing market confidence […]

item.title: Can Jim Chalmers reap a healthy crop with the help of his big worm farm?
item.description: One observer describes next week's economic roundtable this way: "Chalmers has opened a can of worms — and everybody has got a worm."
item.content:encoded: One observer describes next week's economic roundtable this way: "Chalmers has opened a can of worms — and everybody has got a worm."

item.title: Live: ASX rises as Baby Bunting soars 26pc
item.description: The Australian share market has opened higher on Friday, while a hotter-than-expected US producer prices report dampens expectations of potential interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.
item.content:encoded: The Australian share market has opened higher on Friday, while a hotter-than-expected US producer prices report dampens expectations of potential interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

item.title: $10 million theft of baby formula and other items from Melbourne supermarkets
item.description: Police allege people on student and temporary visas have been stealing baby formula, medicines and vitamins from supermarkets in Melbourne, and then passing them to others who then on-sell the items for profit.
item.content:encoded: Police allege people on student and temporary visas have been stealing baby formula, medicines and vitamins from supermarkets in Melbourne, and then passing them to others who then on-sell the items for profit.

item.title: Canberra school dismayed after $50 million expansion walked back
item.description: The ACT government changes its plans for a Canberra school expansion after data showed they expected fewer enrolments than had been predicted during the COVID-19 pandemic.
item.content:encoded: The ACT government changes its plans for a Canberra school expansion after data showed they expected fewer enrolments than had been predicted during the COVID-19 pandemic.

item.title: Live: 30 childcare centres hit with compliance notices under new powers
item.description: Australia's Department of Education has initiated compliance actions against 30 early childcare centres under new powers introduced by the federal government. Follow live.
item.content:encoded: Australia's Department of Education has initiated compliance actions against 30 early childcare centres under new powers introduced by the federal government. Follow live.

item.title: LA Olympics organisers reveal they will break long-standing sponsor rule
item.description: Organisers of the 2028 LA Olympics reveal they have received confirmation from the IOC that sponsor names will be allowed on venues, breaking a long-standing policy.
item.content:encoded: Organisers of the 2028 LA Olympics reveal they have received confirmation from the IOC that sponsor names will be allowed on venues, breaking a long-standing policy.

item.title: Australia's meth, cocaine, MDMA and heroin use up by 34 per cent
item.description: The latest wastewater survey reveals Australians have consumed record amounts of meth, cocaine and heroin.
item.content:encoded: The latest wastewater survey reveals Australians have consumed record amounts of meth, cocaine and heroin.

item.title: 'Urgent' bans on abusive childcare workers to take up to 12 months, says attorney-general
item.description: The attorney-general concedes an "urgent" capability for abusers banned in one state to be banned across every state, to be agreed on at a meeting of ministers today, may not be in place for another 12 months.
item.content:encoded: The attorney-general concedes an "urgent" capability for abusers banned in one state to be banned across every state, to be agreed on at a meeting of ministers today, may not be in place for another 12 months.

item.title: 'I couldn't be more ready': Root eyeing end to Ashes century, win drought in Australia
item.description: Joe Root is closing in on his fourth Ashes tour Down Under, and the former England skipper says he's ready for the challenge of trying to break through for a first Test century and first Test win on Australian soil.
item.content:encoded: Joe Root is closing in on his fourth Ashes tour Down Under, and the former England skipper says he's ready for the challenge of trying to break through for a first Test century and first Test win on Australian soil.

item.title: Australians join international fight to contain Canadian wildfires
item.description: Katanning volunteer Aron Burnett is one of a string of Australians flown in to deal with the worsening fire crisis across central and western Canada.
item.content:encoded: Katanning volunteer Aron Burnett is one of a string of Australians flown in to deal with the worsening fire crisis across central and western Canada.

item.title: Albanese plays down US ‘disgust’ over Palestine recognition
item.description: US ambassador to Israel Mike Huckabee said there was disgust and disappointment in the Trump administration over Prime Minister Anthony Albanese’s move on Palestine.
item.content:encoded: US ambassador to Israel Mike Huckabee said there was disgust and disappointment in the Trump administration over Prime Minister Anthony Albanese’s move on Palestine.

item.title: Tables turned on WA's legal watchdog as it faces inquiry
item.description: The Legal Practice Board of WA, the independent regulator for the state's legal profession, is facing a parliamentary inquiry amid a "detailed list" of complaints about its governance and processes.
item.content:encoded: The Legal Practice Board of WA, the independent regulator for the state's legal profession, is facing a parliamentary inquiry amid a "detailed list" of complaints about its governance and processes.

item.title: David Stratton reminds us not to wait to share the magic of cinema
item.description: I write this to remember David and his incomparable contribution to Australian and world cinema, but also to implore myself and anyone else reading this: don't wait.
item.content:encoded: I write this to remember David and his incomparable contribution to Australian and world cinema, but also to implore myself and anyone else reading this: don't wait.

item.title: Stranded Nullarbor driver watches cars pass him by for two days
item.description: When Caleb Humphries's car broke down on the Nullarbor Plain, he spent two days watching cars drive past him and hoping someone would stop, until help was sent from more than 1,200 kilometres away.
item.content:encoded: When Caleb Humphries's car broke down on the Nullarbor Plain, he spent two days watching cars drive past him and hoping someone would stop, until help was sent from more than 1,200 kilometres away.
